(I also uploaded this video to YouTube, I am Yarii41 on YT if you want to do a search for it).NOTE #2: I used this camera to upload another video for this item: Smart Solar Aquatic Range Floating Lily Solar Fountain This video I used the lowest movie setting, MP4 VGA and it turned out better quality for an Amazon upload than the video above. I remembered to turn on the wind buffer this time!**********This is the first bridge camera I've fallen in love with. It's larger but lighter weight than others, yet the build quality hasn't suffered. It has a lithium-ion battery in place of 4 AA batteries, which helps with the weight and makes the battery door a breeze to close. It has good battery life. Shutter response/focusing/recovery to take the next shot is FAST.As long as you don't mind toting around a large camera, this will work for beginners who want more than a basic Point & Shoot, to more skilled photographers who don't want to carry a DSLR. With a choice of Intelligent or Superior Auto or P/A/S/M this works for a beginner who eventually wants to learn about Shutter Priority, Aperture Priority, Full Manual, Etc. What this camera doesn't have is RAW. That's not a big deal to me because I've never used it, but it may be to YOU and a camera in this price range usually has the ability to shoot RAW.My major complaint is Sony (as well as other manufacturers) think we want higher MP's but they don't increase the sensor size. For this having 20 MP, the 1/2.3 sensor is too small, but having the Bionz CMOS processor seems to help. As a reference I also reviewed the new Sony H200 which has the same size sensor but a Super Had CCD processor and that camera is so much slower with worse images. Of course, that camera is half the price, too.Here is a bag that works: Case Logic DCB-304 High/Fixed Zoom Camera Case (Black)No camera is perfect, I've owned over 50 and haven't found the perfect one yet. This one comes close for a bridge camera.

Reviews.Title: Super for zoom, good as basic camera
Reviews.Author: Ardeal "Emi"
Reviews.Content: First, I am a Sony Digital fan. In 2001 I purchased my first Sony Digital Camera, a 3.2MP Mavica with Carl Zeiss Lens and I thought it served me well for 5 years before moving into semi-pro DSLR cameras with Nikon (D200 and later D7000). Once you step into DSLR-s, it's hard to be a fan of Point-and-shoot cameras. However, this year, I purchased 2 Sony point-and-shoot cameras for my family (the HX10V and WX-50) and received this one for review from Amazon. I was not going to go back to point and shoot - until I got this camera. It is not a perfect camera, yet it has some unbeatable features (The Zoom for pictures and video) that would be very expensive in the DSLR option. I wanted to use it frequently during at least a month before settling on a review for Amazon.NOTE ON THE (AMAZON) AVERAGE STARS for this camera.If you are like me, you look for the average number of stars for Amazon products. In April 2013, this camera had an average 3.5 stars while the HX200 (last year's model) had an average of 4.5 stars despite being an inferior camera in my opinion (no GPS or flip-out screen on the HX300, yet more than 2X better zoom). At the end of May 2013, the HX300 moved up to 4 stars. Even on Snapsort (a site for camera comparisons), the HX300 now scores 1 point  higher than the HX200 (a month ago, the HX200 scored higher).MUST HAVE ACCESSORY: A 55-mm UV filter. I recommend Hoya 55mm HMC UV Digital Multi-Coated Slim Frame Glass Filter. I accidentally fell with my camera, and the only thing that cracked was this filter, the lens was fine. Got a replacement right away.3 REVIEWING ITEMS and my (subjective) grades:BASIC PICTURES - 3.5 STARS. I looks at some other reviews that praised the quality of the pictures yet I was surprised at the large amount of bad pictures I took. And I used other point and shoot cameras for comparison. The Intelligent Auto can be very misleading - I can be zooming in on someone 50 feet away and the info reads it as a macro. I would not recommend this camera to a person new to photography - it is also relatively bulky. Once I adjusted the camera settings manually, I was able to take better pictures. I am also not impressed with the panoramic mode and the way pictures are combined - I believe some less expensive cameras are better at that. One last thing on this topic: in my opinion, the 350 pixels per inch for high quality is nowhere close to cameras with a larger sensor that have 300 or less PPI.SUPER-ZOOM - 5 STARSFor a DSLR to have this type of zoom range, you may have to spend thousands. I can finally took nice pictures of the moon (I uploaded a picture under customer images) and of birds from far away - especially if I use a tripod. I was able to take relatively good pictures of my son playing soccer even right after sunset. Some of the reviewers are disappointed with the quality of pics at full zoom. I got my lesson while taking a picture of the moon: even though I used a tripod, I could see the image shaking from even the lightest vibration and wind gust when focused on the moon. I placed my camera on 2 second delay (with tripod of course) to get the best results. The auto-image stabilizer really does a great job - otherwise all pics would be shaken. Every time you add to the zoom, chances for shake are increased exponentially. That is why cameras such as the wx-50 can have 4.5 stars even though the zoom is only 5X.VIDEO - 5 StarsThe most memorable experience was when I took this camera to some choir practices and performances held at a mega church. During practice, I held it in my hands. During performance, I used a tripod. I can say that both videos look great on a 50-in TV. I sat in rows 6-7, in front of me there was some open 12-15ft.of  space, then about 10 stairs, then some more space (20-25ft) for the performance area, and only in the back there were the bleachers for the choir. I could film the entire choir (each row had about 35 kids) at once, then zoom in to focus on just 1 or 2 faces at one time. I really felt like a kid in candy land with this feature. The focus may not work 100% of the time right away, yet it is very quick to adjust. I definitely prefer this camera even over my digital Camcorder. You can even take pictures while recording video.TOTAL: 4.5 STARS - as a basic camera, I would give it 3-3.5 Stars. As a super-zoom camera for those who understand how to make manual adjustments, I would give it 5. I have to admit - I've been struggling for a month whether this is a 4 star or 5 star product. The limited focus in low light pictures made me go for the 4.UPDATE 6/10/13 After playing with the multiple frame feature at the pool, I have to say that I'm impressed with the 8-10 frames per second feature. I asked my son to do some flips while jumping in the pool and they turned out great - even on a 50-in TV. One neat thing about the camera: you can go through the multiple frames by simply tilting your camera after you take the pictures. I am so impressed with the quality of the pictures (true - it is in broad daylight, not in low light settings) that I upgrade the camera (yet again) to 4.5 stars...

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Carl Galloway
Reviews.Content: I bought the camera from Amazon and I bought a VCT-VPR1 Remote Control Tripod from Sony to go with it.  I highly recommend that you buy both as it is much easier to focus on distant objects with the remote and take pictures without moving the camera.  I have taken great shots of the moon and Jupiter with its moons.  I use the camera mostly for birds and scenery shots and I am extremely pleased with all my pictures.

Reviews.Title: Big Expectations---Poor Results
Reviews.Author: Capt. Aero
Reviews.Content: I've used and enjoyed good performance from the three Sony HX-Series superzoom models that came before the HX300. I tested this new camera for five days and tried all I could, but the photos and videos were only mediocre at best and mostly not worth keeping. Sony found last year what the limit was for Megapixels on a small sensor and also for zoom power, with the HX200V. This year, they've exceeded that limit with the HX300. I sent mine back and bought another HX200V as a backup camera, as I know it will perform very well. I suggest that anyone who is interested in the HX300, do the same. It's hard for me to imagine how others here have given it five stars. I wonder if they were actually testing the same camera?The focusing ability of the HX300 in lower light levels and at high points in the zoom range is slow and unsteady, while my HX200V and the two predecessor models excel at that. I tested the HX300 in good sunlight on subjects I'd shot a short time before with my HX200V. I got some passably-good photos with the HX300, but with many types of subjects, they were very poor. The HX200V photos of many of these subjects had come out nicely and with a minimum of effort. The HX200V shoots outstanding 60p video, but when at the upper end of the zoom range, the HX300 video looks about like standard-definition. Do yourself a favor and pass up this one.Steve McDonald

Reviews.Title: Focus Ring Better Than Chocolate
Reviews.Author: David Mace
Reviews.Content: After a shipping error, I went out to buy the Canon SX50 that I had ordered from a store front... and ended up buying this, instead.What truly sold me on this camera was the big focus ring around the outside of the lens.  It's not mechanically attached to the optics; it's more like a jog/shuttle dial, and has wonderful tactile feedback to it.  Unlike virtually any 'autofocus' capable cameras, where manual focus can be 'touchy', small, deliberate adjustments on the ring make small adjustments to the focus (or zoom, in auto-focus mode).  Do yourself a favor and physically touch one of these, if you're shopping for 'super duper zoom' cameras.  Try it.  You'll understand.  The Canon SX50 manual focus is actually done with tiny thumb ring around the menu buttons, if you can lay hands on that, to compare.The image stabilization is pretty nifty.  Hand-held, zooming way in on a 'Bighorn sheep' on a hillside, I managed to fill the frame with its face.  The focus was a little softer than I wanted, but it was a lot better than I expected on a 50x zoom of something over 100 yards away from me.  On a tripod, with more careful, manual focus, it could only be better.I'm knocking one star off for the buggy firmware and lousy user manual and online documents for the camera.  It got stuck in 'wide aspect' shooting mode, and hid all of the settings to change it back, until I reset the camera from scratch.  I had to wait until I was home, with an internet connection to figure out that it was borked, and needed that reset.  The manual it comes with is thick, only because it comes in lots of languages, all basically pointing at a picture of the camera, with the controls labeled, and telling you how to put the battery in.  That was kind of annoying.  If this was some sort of 'user friendly' mode to hide 'excessive details' from users, it did the opposite, and wasn't covered in the manual.

Reviews.Title: Best of the SuperZooms
Reviews.Author: J. Fox "jfox"
Reviews.Content: The main reasons I chose the Sony HX300 over Canon, Panasonic, or Fuji was the resolution detail and the manual focus ability. Plus the Sony button layout is much more user friendly than the others in it's class. Check the resolution charts on TechRadar and you will see the Sony has the highest resolution detail of them all. What really sold me was the detail in bird feathers when comparing photos taken by the SX50 and the HX300. Take a look at some examples of what the HX300 can do in the hands of a good photographer and you'll see what I mean: [...]

Reviews.Title: great camera
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth Hoerman
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera.  I was worried that the pictures taken with the extreme zoom would not be good quality.  No worries now, all the pictures turn out fantastic.  It is a good camera for those like me who are wanting more than just a point and shoot but not ready to take the plunge buying an SLR camera.

Reviews.Title: Not a good upgrade from Sony DSC H50
Reviews.Author: Jhonny Alfredo Lugo, JL
Reviews.Content: Hobbyist photographer I have been using with great satisfaction a Sony DSC H50 for about 4 years (15x, 9.1 MP, Super Steady Shot). Looking for an upgrade decided to buy a DSC-HX300. During testing found a quite powerful and easy to use camera; the manual focus is handy and works very well. It is a far better and advanced product when compared with my old H50...however is unable to take better pictures. Tried different settings, no better results at all. Note am not saying is not a good camera; "good" and "bad" are relative, it depends a lot from where the buyer is upgrading from. In my case it just did not meet the expectations. Tip: with Nikon D3200 priced $100 more(D3200 also failed to take better pictures than my H50 after 10 days of trial) and Sony A65 priced $200 more, the HX300 seems seriously overpriced.

Reviews.Title: The only camera you really need
Reviews.Author: ARI J COMET
Reviews.Content: Friends/family tell me how much they love their DSLR, but then you look at the cost of money they spent on the body, the lenses and so forth.  We didn't want to make that kind of financial investment, but lets face it sometimes the camera on your phone can't get "close enough" to the action.  Our requirements were simply-- a good quality camera that had a good zoom (better than a point and shoot) but also could take action shots, maybe some other special shots here or there, etc.My wife/I use our phones primarily for most day-to-day functions.  However we wanted to take special event photos with something that could do better, higher res, better optics, etc.  But we didn't want to go down the rabbit hole of a DSLR-- plus neither of us really know much about things like F-stops and apertures (I took some classes years ago, but I didn't retain much).  So we wanted a bit of a "dummy proof" option, but that could still have fun in "manual modes" if we ever wanted to explore.This camera is really nice for all of those ideas above-- it has basic point-to-shoot modes, automatic for just general use.  The next level is to take a photo in a mode (such as firework mode, or similar).  And then from there plenty of manual adjustment modes to play with too!  Sure you are limited to the lens on it, but we have been so thrilled with it thus far.  I'm a huge Sony brand fan, love their interface on the camera and their devices in general.  My only complaint about the camera is the slow render time between photos sometimes.  Otherwise, very pleased and would recommend highly as a really nice bridge camera.EDIT-- Check out more photos taken with this device here in my mini-review:[...]

Reviews.Title: I have owned the Sony DSC-HX300 twice.
Reviews.Author: David L. Winters
Reviews.Content: First of all I want to say that I am a amaturer photographer who prefers power zoom point and shoot cameras. I have owned several film and digital SLR's in the past and wasn't impressed with the cost of the lenses and the cameras. I have owned alot of power zoom cameras mostly Panasonic and Sony. I have had two Sony's so far......The HX100 which I still have and now for the 2nd time the HX300. I sold the first HX300 to my sister in law. I tried playing with some of the new SLR cameras....NIkon D3200 and D5300 and the Canon SL1 and the T5i. I just wasn't impressed with the cost of the cameras and additional lenses. I think the Sony HX300 is capable of so much for such a low price ($418.00 compared with the cost of the SLR's). They run anywhere from $540 to over $1000 by the time you buy a additional zoom lens. The HX300 is great in low light situations because it can go all the way up to ISO 12800. The SLR's can do that for a much higher price for the bigger sensors. The HX300 takes great videos as well. I would recommend this camera because I believe its the best in its class compared to the Canon SX50 and the Panasonic FZ70 which I did own. The Nikon P520 is competition as well. These are all great cameras but I prefer the HX300 over all of them. One thing I would recommend.....Take a look at all the features and specs and do a comparisom with other power zoom cameras and you will see this camera ia a powerhouse of features. The only thing lacking is GPS which I don't want because it will drain the batteries in cameras fast.

Reviews.Title: Has versatility, function, & performance for the price!
Reviews.Author: Michael P
Reviews.Content: This is a very useful and versatile bridge camera for both the point-and-shoot people as well as the enthusiasts. It has the feel of a full-size DSLR but is a bit smaller. The most outstanding feature is its amazing 50x zoom lens (1200mm equivalency), which is capable of zooming like an expensive telescope - bringing far-off objects that cannot be seen by the naked eye, into full view in the frame.It's light-weight, Zeiss lens, image-stabilization, fast auto-focus, and can be used in full-auto features or manual adjust of all key features aperture, shutter, ISO, etc. The lens is 24-1200mm optical. The digital zoom causes images to be a bit soft or grainy, but the digital zoom is really unnecessary when the optical zooms 50X to 1200mm. It records video up to 1920x1080 and can snap HD photo while video recording.It lacks a few of the features possessed by its 30x predecessor (DSC-HX200), but it makes up for that shortcoming with its 50x zoom. And it performs well even with the smaller 1/2.3 sensor. It has a fixed lens and can't support interchangeable lens -- but you won't need other lens with its 24-1200mm range. I think it's a great camera for the money.If you need convincing, read the online reviewers and watch the Youtube vids. This camera has the qualities of both the point&shoot; and the entry-level DSLRs. In low-light, you may need a tripod or a steady hand; in bright sunny light, it's a push-over: sharp, crisp images along with the option of blurring the backgrounds intentionally.I recommend these companions with this HX300 camera: Sony VF-55MPAM lens protective filter;  Sony NP-BX1/M8 Lithium-Ion X Type Battery and/or Wasabi  Charger# KIT-BTR-NPBX1-LCH-NPBX1-01; and Lowepro Adventura-120 Camera Bag w/soft orange velour lining and perfect fit for HX300, with compartments for extra batteries, SD cards, lens cloth, etc .ALSO: I found the User's GUIDE  for HX300 -- it's a great help, better than the manual I think. Here is the link to download GUIDE:[...]

Reviews.Title: Image Quality Not As Good as Sony HX100
Reviews.Author: D. Hatcher "4jenesaispas"
Reviews.Content: Purchased and returned because the image quality is not as good as Sony's HX100 which I own. Images at long zoom ranges are generally of poor quality. Disappointed that image quality is not better.

Reviews.Title: Amazing
Reviews.Author: Franz
Reviews.Content: This is an amazing Camera. Nothing like I experienced before. No blurry or unfocused pictures. The zoom is just incredible. The video HD quality is superb. Very smooth playback on my quad core HP. The only complaint which really has no impact on the performance of the camera but I wish that the software installation process was less time consuming for the video portion and DVD burning. All in all I am extremely happy especially since I have started using the camera on 3-15-2013 and people that pre-ordered this camera directly from the Sony site paid more money and are still waiting for the camera. Amazon rules.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Quality.
Reviews.Author: Barbara Wrede
Reviews.Content: I was so excited for this camera to become available.  I currently shoot with a sony DSLR, but I wanted something to take with me when I didn't want all my lenses.  It just came last night so I didn't get to use it much.  The tilting ability of the LCD is an awesome feature.  Lots of bells and whistles, but it is crazy to see the zoom lens seem to come out of nowhere in this device.  I know some of the reviews state that it is heavy, but being used to the sony dslr, this seems to be the perfect weight.  I wanted something substantial for control, but not heavy to hold.Absolutely love it!

Reviews.Title: A Dream Camera For Me!
Reviews.Author: Dr. Johnson C. Philip "Author of over 100 boo...
Reviews.Content: I am a compulsive photographer, and started shooting people and objects when I was 15. A friend presented me with my first digital camera when I was 45, and life has never been the same again. That was Sony Mavica, and it used 3.5 inch floppy disks to store pictures. The highest resolution was only 1.2 mega pixels, but with its 16x optical magnification it did wonders for me.This is my fourth digital Camera in 15 years. In fact the moment I read the specification and the Sony name, I sold my non Sonly Digital Single Lens Reflex (DSLR) camera, removable lens, and telephoto lens (puchased for a futune) at a loss and bought this model. Once again, life has never been the same again after I bought it.Here are some of the features*** It offer 20+ Mega-pixel resolution, something that can do wonders*** It offer and unbelievable 50x OPTICAL magnification, again something that can do wondersCare to Take:*** The camera offers so much in terms of resolution and optical magnification that most users need to learn afresh that a powerful tool can be used in unbelievable way. Do explore all the possibilities*** Do use a monopod or a tripod for shooting at magnifications greater than 20xUniqueness:*** High resolution*** Super-high magnification*** Ability to keep the flash off in any and every situation (a manual switch is provided)*** All other standard software features are available*** Very light and ergonomic designRecommendation:*** If ease of use, high resolution, and high optical magnification is your need, then this is THE camera for you*** It is very economically pricedI have been using this Camera now for 3 months and for me it is dream come true.

Reviews.Title: Not perfect but a great all around camera
Reviews.Author: Shane O. Laake "camera nerd"
Reviews.Content: As much as I'd love to have a perfect superzoom camera that can do everything, I know there are compromises inherent with size, cost, and image quality.  There's only so much Sony's software and hardware wizardry can do to combat that, though they do manage to throw the kitchen sink of features in there.  All in all, I really like this camera.Having lugged around lenses that rival newborns in size and weight (and even in out of pocket costs), I've learned to appreciate compact, lightweight, and affordable solutions (all relative).  With this in mind, I understood there would be some trade offs.  All three meant using a smaller more cost effective sensor, which means smaller pixels, and a greater challenge to take pictures at night or accommodate a faster shutter (via raising ISO).  Likewise all three mean using a lens with a variable aperture, which gets a bit small (higher F#) on the telephoto end, which again hinders pictures in low light or requiring a fast shutter.  Only magic can fix these inherent challenges, and absent of that I expect these issues.As for the rest, well it's all rather well done.  In good light this camera takes great images.  On clear days the 50x zoom is amazing, but do know if there's haze, that's a lot of haze between you and your distant subject being captured in your images (again only magic can fix that).  The panorama mode is amazing, movies solid, and the video is rather nice.  Ergonomics are solid, and battery life, while not ideal, is good enough.Ideally I'd like to see a better 12mp sensor that greatly enhances high ISO performance, but I understand consumer behavior and the push for more MP.  Sony does an OK job of addressing things with software, but I'd rather see a move towards "ultra pixels" (to steal a term from HTC).  This and the lack of an articulated screen cause the camera to lose a star.These opportunities aside, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Sony moving backward
Reviews.Author: Marilyn Patterson
Reviews.Content: I have owned the 50, Hx-1, HX200 and now the 300.  The best camera they made was the HSC50, The HX-1 is ok as a back-up camera. All three of those had one great feature that they eliminated in the HX300.  That is the lens cap falling off when you turn the camera on.  It is caught by the string so you cannot lose it.  It makes it fast to grab your camera a shoot moving birds. I have to fumble with the lens cap to get it off of the 300. I use all of my cameras on Automatic for speed and have always gotten shots to be made into posters and powerpoints.  Also as a bird and wildlife photographer I always carry extra charged batteries.  All of my other Sonys were designed with a charger so that you could charge the battery out of the camera.  The 300 can only be charged through the camera. Having the camera sitting on the floor (the cord is too short to reach other outlets) with a large dog in the house is asking for trouble.  Also everyone knows that you should never plug your camera directly a wall outlet or computer as the chance of damage to the camera is huge.  I have made a couple of good close-ups of frogs but when you use the zoom the photos seem fake.  It does a poor job on photos with artificial light.  They also eliminated the option of using the flash on other than auto.  Because of the type of photography I do, I need speed and good automatic settings.  This camera is so slow recording the images on zoom that I can only get one shot where as on the others I could get 5.  The body is bulky and very light which makes it awkward to hold.  I use the peep site all of the time so it is ok for me but I wouldn't want to have to hold it out from my eye for any length of time. The other models felt more solid in the hand.  I owned the HX200 but it broke a week after buying it, was repaired, then broke again at 14 months (out of warrantee) and they said it would cost $160 to fix.  I should have bought another 200 with an extended warrantee but after my old one dying on vacations twice I was gun shy. The manual that comes with it sucks.It doesn't tell you how to get it off of digital zoom.  I would not recommend this camera to photographers who care about the quality of the images. I have had it a few weks and so far I am not impressed.

Reviews.Title: very slow writing speed
Reviews.Author: osakajoe
Reviews.Content: I am a parent of two young children. We wanted a camera that was not too heavy for travel, but with a nice zoom to be able to capture moments when the kids are at one end of the pool or field or stage and we're at the other. I also wanted a quick camera for action shots and sports events. I was so, so disappointed with this camera because the 1.5-2.5 second delay between the time you snap the photo and the time it's its ready for the next shot (in other words, the writing speed or how long it takes the image to record onto the memory card) is unacceptable. It really feels like an eternity before you can click again!!!! Certainly, you can set it to burst mode and take multiple shots with one click, but then you still have to wait 3-4 seconds for it to write before you can initiate the next burst.  And this is with use of a ScanDisk HD 32GB/80 MB card, the fastest available! I was surprised not to see more reviews about the slow writing speed on line when I was researching.  If you're looking to take action shots of your kids or pets, this is likely not the camera for you.

Reviews.Title: Does not live up to the description or marketing
Reviews.Author: nefarr
Reviews.Content: Admittedly I have previously used a Nikon D90 which is known for its crisp photos. The D90 is a 12 MP camera and the DSC HX300 is a 20 MP camera. When you read that a camera is about the sensor and not the pixels, believe it. The Sony DSC HX300 may have almost twice the pixel count, but the pictures are not even half as good, as sharp or with as much detail.The auto focus does function, but very very slowly. That one word describes almost every feature of the camera - SLOW. The zoom is exceedingly slow and the auto  focus even slower. I used the camera with a Class 10 SDHC 32GB card that functions superbly fast in my Nikon, but takes one to two seconds to write from the Sony DSC HX300. While this may not seem like much of a delay, it is significant if you want to take more than one picture of an object. Children, animals, sports and most other live photo opportunities just don't stand still and wait for you to shoot one picture, wait for the camera to write to the card, then shoot another. If an object is moving, all you will get is a blur no matter the ISO setting used.The camera is supposed to work well for sports, wildlife and other normal types of shots. It doesn't. Again, the delays in shooting, focusing and zooming spoil many photo opportunities. I tried taking pictures of my dogs at play which is easy with the Nikon, but almost impossible with the Sony.While the camera advertises that it will shoot bursts at a high rate of speed this is not the case when using a higher quality image. I knew that the camera did not take pictures in RAW, but the JPG even at the finest resolution the Sony is capable of is simply not up to par.I very much wanted this camera to work for me, as it would significantly replace the amount and weight of gear I would have to take with me on a day outing or for travel. It is so light and plastic-y that it is hard to steady properly anywhere past half zoom. The build quality seems lacking and more toy-like than most cameras I have used.The instructions that come with the camera flat out state that the camera will pick up noise from the shutter and the zoom if you use it with movie mode. It does. I tried the movie mode, and while the picture was fairly good, you could clearly hear the motor of the zoom and some other extraneous noise from the camera on the playback.I dislike reviews that totally pan an item. It always sounds to me like the writer has it in for the manufacturer or there is something else driving the bad review. I wish that were the case here. For the first time, I am writing a review that really downgrades an item.  I did a good bit of on-line research about the ultra-zoom bridge camera sector and thought that based on pre-release reviews and analysis of the camera that it would be a hit. Unfortunately I just couldn't recommend this camera to anyone whether a novice, enthusiast or other user.The summary is that unless you want the camera to take pictures of static objects like scenery, buildings, statues or the like, this isn't the camera for you. It definitely doesn't work for vacations, action, children, pets, wildlife or anything that moves.This has nothing to do with my review of the camera, but be careful about buying this item from Amazon or any dealer on-line for that matter. I am trying to return the camera, but Amazon is telling me that there is no refund on this item. I didn't see that warning when I bought the camera, but you should be aware of that. If you make a mistake buying this camera, you're probably stuck with it. For me, it was an expensive lesson.

It sure beats my first  Kodak "Brownie"... After I got back and downloaded what I had, I saw a commercial on TV for a Microsoft cell-phone with a built-in 40 megapixel camera! Is there no end to it? I bought my first digital Canon for $1,000 in 2006 and the sensor was only good for 3.3 megapixels, a Ford Model A compared to an Audi A-7... This camera is well worth the $450 price tag but it's soon to be out-done by carbon nano-circuitry. Ain't it great to live in our time!

Reviews.Title: Great camera with sometimes inconsistent results
Reviews.Author: J. Harley
Reviews.Content: The HX300 is a megazoom bridge camera.  It's fairly large when compared to typical digicams.  However, it is still smaller than most DSLRs, if even by only a little.  Ergonomically, the camera feels good.  The body is constructed of plastic which makes the camera lighter than it appears.  I personally like the controls placement. Everything is neatly and logically arranged.  The top has jog and mode dials which should be familiar to anyone who has previously used a DSLR or bridge camera before.  There were no head scratching moments when looking for controls or features.Size and Weight---------------The size and weight of the HX300 are pretty decent for the type.  It fits somewhere in the middle on the size scale for bridge cameras.  For example, it's larger than the Canon SX50 but smaller than the Fuji HS50.  The plastic body looks deceivingly heavy but is actually lighter than I expected.  I have no problems handholding the camera for steady shots, but personally, this would be strictly a specialty camera and not my first choice to lug around somewhere like Disney World all day.  That's not a knock against the camera because even my smaller (body) NEX 5N isn't my first choice.  That would be my Canon S100, a tiny camera that takes excellent stills, video and is small enough to be unobtrusive while I'm running around the park. The HX300 would be my first choice for sporting events, wildlife photography, vacation photos around the resort (where I could easily stow the camera away when finished), weddings, graduations, shows, or any other event where I would benefit from having as long a zoom as possible. That's not to say the HX300 won't make a suitable every day camera, because it most certainly would.  I just prefer not to haul a large camera around all day, and make no mistake, this is a large camera when compared to standard non-megazoom digicams.Performance-----------Performance so far has pretty decent.  The camera starts up relatively quickly and the auto-focus is very good with no excessive hunting. The controls are conveniently placed and everything is within easy reach.  The menus are logically arranged and super easy to navigate, even easier than my NEX touchscreen.  The speed is great.  I sometimes get a little shutter lag in dim light depending upon the circumstances, even with the flash enabled, but at least so far I've experienced no excessive write delays between shots.  In bright light, like an outdoor sunny day, there is no delay whatsoever and the camera is very snappy and responsive.  That's important for shooting situations like an outdoor sporting event, where a slow camera can really ruin your day.  So far, I've had no problems focusing on moving subjects, even fast moving. There is no RAW mode which is sort of a bummer for enthusiasts but won't bother most shooters. The quality of the jpegs can range from excellent to downright awful.  More on that in the next paragraph. Video mode shoots 1080p video.  Focusing during video is usually good and the internal microphone does a decent job of capturing sounds without excessive background or wind noise.  You can zoom during recording without excessive internal mechanical noises ruining the sound.  It has a dedicated video button, so switching from still to video mode is not only easier but also allows both to be used simultaneously.  It also eliminates the possibility of mixing up the two while shooting.  I've had numerous occasions where I've missed still shots on other cameras due to forgetting to turn the dial back to still after shooting a video clip.  The rear tilting 3" LCD is very sharp.  The sharpness is a double edge sword because sometimes pics look great on the LCD until transferred to a larger screen.  You can adjust the brightness and resolution on the rear LCD to conserve battery life.  The LCD doesn't swing outward, so no easy self-portraits.  That's not a big deal for me personally, but it may be for some.  It also has an EVF that actually isn't too bad.  Burst mode so far has been okay but I only tested it sparingly and admittedly haven't yet gone beyond 5 or so frames, which all came out great in good light.Image quality--------------Image quality is sometimes a mixed bag.  For example, I took numerous outdoor and indoor shots in a variety of lighting conditions, from partly-cloudy to bright and sunny.  Most of the pictures taken outdoors in perfect lighting came out perfect, not surprisingly.  Focus was spot-on and the images were sharp, clear and colors were vibrant, even when enlarged.  None of the pictures taken in the overcast conditions were keepers.  Some were mediocre while others were downright terrible, with tons of artifacts and pretty shoddy focus especially at the far end of the zoom.  I can forgive the bad photos at the far end of the zoom, especially taken hand-held, but I honestly expected a little better dim light outdoor performance.  However, the most perplexing photos were the ones taken in bright sunlight of complex scenery.  For instance, I tried to take some pictures of the woods behind my home to test how well the autofocus responds to challenging focusing situations.  I was very disappointed.  My cheap sub-$100 digicam handles focusing of complex scenery better.  When the camera failed to take a decent photo of the entire scene, I focused on specific trees and branches, hoping for better results.  I got the same results, blurry photos regardless of focal length (so no more blaming the zoom).  If I focused on a less complex targets, like my patio or other nearby inanimate objects, the camera focused fine.  I could usually correct the issue by manually adjusting ISO and focus but this review is mainly for the set it and forget it crowd, not serious amateurs and pros.  Also, it's not exactly impossible to photograph those woods on full auto because a Canon SX40 that I tried last year had no problem doing so (Although, the SX40 did have its own different focusing issues at times).  I also tested with an older Fuji S1800 using comparable settings and it seems like the Fuji does a better job of automatically setting exposure settings for that particular shot.  Switching from intelligent auto to superior auto, which is basically Sony's fancy term for HDR, helped a little but not as much as just taking matters into my own hands.  Indoors, the HX300 took great natural light pictures in bright to even low light.  There will be occasional blur if zoomed out, even a little, while hand-held shooting in dim light.  The HX300 flash is powerful, too powerful at times and makes it very easy to overexpose or wash out your subject if you're not careful.  Another issue with image quality is internal processing.  Sometimes, it's way off.  When the internal compression and processing is really off, the results range from a cartoonish effect to some portions of the photo appearing as if they were shot through a screen.  This also mainly tends to occur with shots taken in dimmer light where the camera can sometimes make some pretty funky exposure choices.Wrap-up-------I like the HX300, but the sometimes inconsistent focusing and image quality make it very easy to see why opinions of this camera vary widely.  Some love it, some hate it.  Depending on their experience level and what they're shooting, I can understand either opinion.  If I had no photography experience and therefore were unable to easily correct some of the camera's shortcomings, I might be disappointed as well.  A camera should take a majority of decent or at least acceptable photos on full auto.  Manual controls and settings are good to have but not everyone wants to learn the fundamentals of photography.  Those who don't should still be able to take decent photos without constantly worrying whether they'll be acceptable or not.  I also have a few hardware gripes with this camera.  First, is the lack of a dedicated battery charger. The HX300 comes with a wall plug that plugs into the camera to charge the battery.  Charging through the camera is a nice option but Sony should have still included a separate battery charger. It may seem petty until you consider that if I buy a spare battery, a very common practice, I'm now also required to pony up an additional $50 (MSRP) for the battery charger as well.  Sure, I could simply use the camera to charge both, but that means I won't have a camera whenever one battery is charging.  That's fine if I can always charge both batteries before leaving but what happens if it becomes likely that I will exhaust both batteries before I'm finished shooting for the day?  Instead of charging one while I continue to shoot with the other, the camera will have to sit out of commission for a few hours while one or both recharges. That eliminates much of the convenience of having a spare battery.  Adding insult to injury is the fact that the USB cable provided for charging and PC connectivity is insanely short.  It's about 2-feet long (a couple inches are the connectors).  I currently charge with my camera near the floor because the cable is too short to reach a counter top.  Even if it could, the cable would be stretched, increasing the likelihood of an inadvertent tumble.  So, I place a book on the floor and charge the camera atop the book.  Another issue is the threads on the lens.  I placed a UV filter on the lens as many others have also done.  I mainly did so because I know I'll be transporting and using this camera to a lot at public events which increases the possibility of damage.  The problem is, despite the camera having threads, officials at Sony claim the camera is not supported to work with anything attached to the threads.  My filters seem to fit okay but I wouldn't trust using any heavier accessories.  Then again, Sony also states in their website specs that the camera doesn't have a viewfinder, which it clearly does, so make of that what you will.  My last gripe is the lack of a hot shoe.  Like the battery charger, it just seems like unnecessary cost cutting on a camera like this.Regardless of the shortcomings, the HX300 is still a great camera.  It's fast and when the exposure is on the money, produces outstanding results.  When dealing with a camera with the zoom capabilities of this one, some tradeoffs are to be expected.  It really depends on your needs and comfort level sometimes compensating if the autoexposure settings just won't cut it.

Reviews.Title: It is OK but should be better
Reviews.Author: D "D"
Reviews.Content: The pictures I took are good and seem to be good quality, the super zoom ones are fuzzy though and not worth printing. I saw mention of a sports mode but I can't find it. I find the menu options a little confusing myself. I don't like the lens cover seems to have no way of attaching it to the camera itself so I can see that getting lost pretty quick, I have a nice fujifilm camera that the lens cover has a small cord so the cover doesn't get lost. The sony HX300 is a bit bulky but it isn't very heavy for the size. It definitely isn't a pocket camera which I would prefer if I were on vacation because of the ease of handling and carrying. I am not an expert on any camera and I am more of a point and shoot person which is what this camera seems to be targeted for. I have a small Sony cybershot that takes pictures that are as good as this camera does and it was cheaper and more compact. The flash is not automatic either, you have to press the button to make the flash open which is something I could live with if the zoom pictures were better. I like to use the zoom function for animals because when you move towards them they move towards you. The time lapse between shots is slow also when in auto mode. I would very much prefer to be able to take shots at any time instead of having to wait so long for the camera to be ready for the next shot since animals and kids just don't sit still.So while this is a good camera it could be better and I am not sure if I would buy it at this price. The zoom just doesn't work as well as it should and that is what they are using as a selling point.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Sony camera, great system.
Reviews.Author: Frank Romo Jr.
Reviews.Content: I purchased this item a year ago and have used it quite frequently. I've also purchased several Wasabi batteries to go with it and placed them against the Sony battery, four stars. This camera works very well for my needs, I also have the Sony HX200V and it's a good back-up system for this camera. I just purchased the Sony H400 & the HX400B; tried them both for a day each and returned them, reason was too complicated for this 67 year old guy. The menus weren't user friendly like the HX200 and HX300, trying to navigate was a lesson in futility. I don't have the patience for fiddling around with several different pages of set-up.The way I feel out my cameras, if I can't work the camera within the first 30 minutes, it's a dead deal. Don't get me wrong, I've got the A-850, the A-77 and the A-580, I know that I have to spend time getting the camera in it's appropriate mode but with a bridge-camera, it shouldn't have to be that difficult.I'll say the Sony system is good but, I just want to keep it simple, I'm sure the 400's will prove themselves but I'll pass them to the ones who have the patience for them. I'll give them a good rating but not for me...

Reviews.Title: New Sony Camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I bought my first Sony camera, Carl Zeiss lens, in 2007 to take continuous photos of my children's track team.  The pictures were outstanding and the camera lasted until fall 2013.  I replaced it with this Sony and I am even happier.  The manual focus is much easier, the 50x zoom is great, and the photos are beautiful.Do spend $7 and get a lens cap with an attachment string.  Really, Sony?  You couldn't include that?

Reviews.Content: I purchased the HX300 to replace my 200 that I left on an airplane.  I like this camera, but to use the zoom at 50 definitely requires a tripod, whereas I could use the 200 fully zoomed out without a tripod.  Consequently, the quality of my photos were, I felt, superior to those that I get with this camera. Given the choice, I would rather have my 200 back.

Reviews.Title: Full range of zoom is not useful
Reviews.Author: KNSudha
Reviews.Content: The OIS is useless at the long end of the zoom range -- I don't find much improvement in usable pictures taken with this vs last years model the HX200 which I really liked and still own. I bought this to use for wildlife on vacation and every photo taken at more than half way through the zoom range results in an unacceptably soft image.  Its still awesome through half of the zoom range, so won't take off all the stars.  Having a bridge cam at a nice price that can put the equivalent of a 600mm lens at hand for fun if not pro quality photos is good to have.  Being spoilt by L lenses, have passed this on to family members, and am much happier with the RX10 also from sony, albeit at 3x the price, which does deliver exactly the promised IQ all the way through its much smaller zoom range.

Reviews.Title: good camera with digital image processing issues
Reviews.Author: Frankenfeld, Fred
Reviews.Content: After Amazon cancelled my order for an "announced", high-zoom, compact, Lumix camera that had not been released, I re-evaluated available options.  I searched the Amazon site for "ultra zoom, viewfinder, compact, GPS camera" and this camera "matched".  The camera is ultra zoom and has a viewfinder...  the camera is NOT compact and does not provide GPS encoding...  (User error caused mismatch?)  The camera almost was returned after taking two images because of SIGNIFICANT delay between pressing the shutter button and processing of the image. Nevertheless, I kept the camera - my solution is to take photos in "sports" or "action" mode (probably, the image processing takes just as long as when other modes are used - processing just seems to occur faster).  Not convinced I got my money's worth - but I am convinced this will NOT be the last camera I buy (I'm 69 years old) because I'm certain that there will be many cameras that meet my criteria without the compromises of this model, a Sony camera will not be my next purchase.  Note: High resolution was not specified in my search criteria, but this camera has 20 mp resolution.

Reviews.Title: Nice zoom, but not my first choice Sony
Reviews.Author: Jacx "J.C."
Reviews.Content: What I likeThe reason I chose this camera was for the zoom, you can pull in some otherwise unattainable shots with this.I really like the jog button.You can change out the battery and SD card with tripod adapter screwed on, just barely.What I don't likeThe screen is exposed on back of camera all the time. It cannot be flipped shut.Although the skin of the camera is similar to my Sony A57 the Lens body looks and feels very plastic.What I wish it had,A remote Shutter release option. I use a tripod often and like the least amount of camera movement I can get.  I do a lot of low light shots, night landscapes, etc.Battery charges in camera, and you can't use while charging. I ended up buying a charger and extra batteries.I feel this camera compliments my Sony A57 which I love more everyday but don't yet have a good zoom lens for and was hoping this camera would fill the gap.  Most times I get the shot, and sometimes I don't.  Even though the zoom can be incredible at times, the delay between shutter release, actual picture taken and processing speed at low light levels just doesn't leave me satisfied.update 9/13I moved my star rating up from three to a four because I really enjoy using this camera piggy back on my telescope, it pulls in some sky shots that would be hard with any other camera I currently have.I also updated on a question someone asked and amazon asked me to answerthis camera will except 55mm filters on front with out issues when camera shuts down, the lens is able to retract no problem.I also use my old Canon filters that are 58mm with a step ring, you can get a whole set here on Amazon for around twelve bucks.

I also did not like that you could not have the LCD/finder on at the same time. Reviews.Title: HX 300: Like telephoto pics; manual lousy, can't take vertical pictures
Reviews.Author: Donald E. L. Johnson "Blogger at businessword...
Reviews.Content: I just bought this camera locally from a guy who knows cameras inside out and convinced me that this beats the Nikon Coolpix P520 and Canon SX50 as well as my 3-4 year-old Nikon P90.While the reason I like the telephoto bridge/zoom cameras is that I like to shoot wildlife from great distances. We're about to embark on a drive to Alaska, and the HX300 looks like a good solution.But, as usual with camera makers, the manual and users' guide are terse to the point of being almost useless.For example, when I try to take vertical (portrait) pictures of trees, towers, people, etc., the LCD screen and view finder black out. I've searched the web high and low for an answer.Because I may return this camera, I haven't registered it. Thus, I can't post a question on the Sony Cybershot forum, which is what I usually do when I have questions about products and issues.As previous reviewers have noted:1. The camera is very slow in extending the telephoto lens and retracting it. But it does extend and retract very smoothly. Similarly, the time it takes to process a shot and give you a chance to another one is way too long when you're trying to take wildlife and action shots. I'm still mulling that problem.2. The features are so numerous that few users will go beyond iScene. I've used SLR cameras since the 50s and have some experience with setting apertures and speeds, but I'm  the kind of user who learns just enough to get my jobs done.3. Online tutorials are nice, but they're too basic and don't help trouble shoot.4. The camera feels pretty good in my hands. I'm amazed that I can get distant shots that stop action pretty well without a tripod.5. I like having the ability to put a protective filter on the lens.6. Attaching the strap was a pain, thanks to designers who apparently don't use or setup cameras.So I'm here on day two, pretty pleased with my initial shots but not so happy with Sony manual or support or forums.But, then, Sony has never gotten Apple and Macs, which is why it's still only Sony, not Apple and it doesn't make anything like Macs or provide the kind of support Apple does. Part of Mike Camera's deal is that you get a 45-minute training session with the sales person on your schedule. I'm hoping Marc can resolve my frustrations and help me get to the next level with the HX300.

Reviews.Title: Be Careful Where You Buy Your HX300
Reviews.Author: Amazonian Consumer
Reviews.Content: I bought my Sony HX300 from a store that offers both officially imported and gray market versions of Sony's products. Although the price difference isn't that great for the HX300, I decided to buy the gray market model to save a few bucks. After arriving home, I tried out the camera, and it was then that I discovered something really peculiar.Depending on the country, the video standard is mostly either NTSC or PAL. The Sony HX300 box differentiates the two versions by marking "60i" for NTSC and "50i" for PAL, in a very hard to notice place. This is also indicated on the bottom of the camera, again, very hard to notice.The camera that I bought had "60i" printed on the box and on the label at the bottom of the camera, BUT when I tried to setup the camera's various configurations, I discovered that the video standard was actually "50i", or PAL! Other than that Sony may have erroneously labelled a 50i/PAL version of HX300, I don't understand how this could be. I returned the camera to the store and got the officially imported version after paying the price difference.So the lesson here is either always buy the officially imported model, or fully test the gray market model before you leave the store, as some stores may not let you return an opened merchandise.

Reviews.Title: dissapointed for the price
Reviews.Author: Edgar J. Puckett
Reviews.Content: I bought a Sony DSC-H1 when they first came out and really liked it, so when I dropped it and smashed the LCD display last week I decided to upgrade.  I figured that with the advanced options and that in the 6 or 8 years since my original purchase it would be a much improved camera.  the 50x optical zoom is good, and the selection of options for photography are nice, however it's pictures are no sharper than my old DSC-H1 were.  I also take a lot of pictures outdoors, frequently while standing in sunlight, so I need the Electronic View Finder.  To my dismay The EVF is such a low resolution that it is barely useable for normal photography, and useless for focusing, framing, etc. if the zoom is turned up much.  In addition, the image software that I downloaded from Sony will not allow me to choose where the image is stored, but only in the default location.I saw a note about not having owner/user manuals that could be downloaded, but I had no trouble downloading one from Sony that I could store on my computer or print as I needed.  That part is good.I believe the camera is a fairly good camera, but not for the price, and not for my use.  I have requested a return on it.

Reviews.Title: Sony made this? Returned

Reviews.Content: Well, I couldn't believe after having Sony cameras for over 15 years that this was camera actually made by Sony. Poor quality pictures, mostly blurry if any action. I returned this camera.

Reviews.Title: No printable user guide
Reviews.Author: Paul N.
Reviews.Content: After purchasing the camera, I was shocked to learn that instead of placing a PDF version of the User Guide on their web site,, Sony has posted a series  of hyperlinks.  You can no longer read or print  a PDF file because there isn't one.This is a complicated, multi-function camera - I want a manual.  I want to read, underline, use the index - you know Read The Manual .  With a hardcopy manual, I can take it with me on photo shoots and refer to it, not hope I have internet connectivity on my outing.Sony Support is of no help.  There are 2 ultimate solutions for me.  One, I should regularly check back to their site to see if the PDF has been posted.  Or, call for help even if it is just to figure out what options might be available to play with for a particular shot.  Do either of these seem reasonable to you?

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera!
Reviews.Author: J. Hansen
Reviews.Content: This is the first DSLR Camera I have owned. I am no expert on a camera like this. I am learning about this camera as I go, and discover something new about it each time I use it. The first thing I noticed about the camera is it's surprisingly lightweight. There are many features and modes to this camera. Not only can you take photographs, but you can shot movies as well .You can select a mode to take pictures in the following situations/places: the beach, snow, fireworks, background defocus, nighttime, food, pets. You can also just select an automatic setting, and it will detect if you have enough light, if your subject is moving, if your subject is a baby, etc. You can manually set the shutter speed and  the aperture value. I love the zoom capabilities on this camera. I recently filmed my daughters dance recital, and I was far from the front of the stage. I was amazed at how much I could zoom in and get a close up of my daughter, as if I were right on the stage with her. Another feature I discovered is that you can set it to detect when your subject smiles. All you do is select that setting, point the camera at your subject, and when he/she smiles, the camera will automatically take a picture. An excellent feature, especially when taking pictures of kids -- no more trying to push the button the moment they smile, the camera does it for you! I'm excited to learn more about this camera, and discover all that it can do.
